title: Will we ever get another mechanically simple champion?
body:
Champions like Garen, Nunu, Ashe (prerework), fiddle, and Evelynn have simple yet effective kits and aren't infinitely mobile. They're unique and really simple mechanically. Do you ever think we will get another champion which is like that? Simple?

It might be because I prefer ult mobility champs or speed boosts over dashes but I just miss this design perspective.

{{champion:157}} I'm not sure I have to call this champion complex and defend it. This should be clear.

{{champion:236}} He's fine too complexity wise my only problem with him is he also has an ability (passive) dubbed too powerful for a melee champ (Yi)

{{champion:14}} This is EXACTLY what I mean. He has a unique and awesome kit. His "Mobility" is his ultimate much like malphite and the rest of his kit is useful and creates a really cool and solid champ without mobility creep, without overloaded or excessively complex kits. 

So of the recently released champs you have more or less 4/11 which are simple with 1 sort of in the middle (Jinx)  and 6/11 champs being complex, and in most cases complex in the extreme. 

This isn't to say we should never get one or the other but it just feels like most champs are  extreme mobility creeped  or they are extremely complex.

Cool, thanks for breaking that out. Based on other responses, that seems to be how people see it too. Just to add in my views, here's how I personally would break it down.

**Mechanically Complex**
{{champion:157}} {{champion:268}} {{champion:429}}

**Mechanically Moderate**
{{champion:421}} {{champion:236}} {{champion:150}} {{champion:222}}

**Mechanically Simple**
{{champion:161}} {{champion:201}} {{champion:14}} {{champion:432}}

Not too far off from other opinions overall, but I seem to skew toward viewing them on the simpler side. Good to check that sense against yours! Bard is the big outlier for me, where everybody else is putting him at high complexity, so I'll throw in my thoughts there:

I'm looking at this purely in terms of mechanical skill, which I determine from two main questions:

1. How quick/precise do I need to be with my inputs to do the things I want to do?
2. How many input decisions do I need to make in a short period of time (~5-10 seconds) to do the things I want to do?

For example, I find Kalista to be mechanically complex because of #1 - she requires a lot of quick and precise inputs to jump where you want (especially as you gain AS). Yasuo is more an example of #2, where you have to make a lot of decisions in a short period of time to move around how you want to and set up knockups.

Really, it boils down to the **moment-to-moment complexity** - how hard is this champion to play in isolation?

But there's another kind of complexity, which I would call strategic complexity.

1. How much forethought (tracking cooldowns, overall map situation, etc.) do I need to have when playing this champion?
2. How much do I need to react to other champions, on both teams (their positioning, skills, etc.), when playing this champion?

For example, Teleport is a strategic spell, largely because of #1. Ezreal, by contrast, isn't too strategic; looking at #2, you kind of don't care who is on either team. You just do Ezreal things regardless.

This is the **minute-to-minute complexity** - how hard is this champion to play in relation to the game state?

Here's how I would break out these champs in strategic complexity:

**Strategically Complex**
{{champion:432}}{{champion:421}} {{champion:150}} {{champion:157}} 

**Strategically Moderate**
{{champion:268}} {{champion:222}} {{champion:429}} {{champion:14}} 

** Strategically Simple**
{{champion:236}} {{champion:201}} {{champion:161}} 

I think it's the combination of the two that makes a champion "simple" or "complex" overall.

So for Bard, I think he's simple on a moment-to-moment basis (mechanical). If you know what you're trying to do (stun that guy, heal that guy, Zhonya's that tower, take a magical journey through that wall, wheeeeeee!), it's fairly straightforward to do them. But knowing WHAT things to do, and when, gets harder. That's the minute-to-minute, and he's pretty complex there. And overall, I think it combines to make an overall complex champion.

So lastly, here's how I would break them out in terms of overall complexity:

**Complex Overall**
{{champion:432}} {{champion:157}} {{champion:268}} {{champion:429}} 

**Moderate Overall**
{{champion:421}} {{champion:150}} {{champion:222}} {{champion:236}} 

**Simple Overall**
{{champion:14}} {{champion:161}} {{champion:201}} 

Whew.... long wall of text there. If you read through it all, thanks! Remember, this is just my personal point of view. I'm curious if it makes sense, and if you all agree/disagree with any of that.

Do you think we're skewing too far on particular kind of complexity? Is it more of an overall complexity? Other thoughts? Fire away! I tend to prefer champs that lean more on the simple side myself, so really want to get a sense of how other players feel.

Personally, I'm fine with complex champions, so long as their complexity doesn't limit the interactions and counterplay of their opponents.

When their complexity allows them, with sufficient mechanical skill, to counter anything that their opponent can do, or at least makes the complex champion's player's skill have a much larger effect in the matchup than their opponent's skill, then that is a really bad design in my eyes.

For example, {{champion:268}} is really mechanically complex, but he still only does a few specific things (mostly DPS and zone control), and has a lot of weakness in other areas.

Meanwhile, {{champion:157}} and {{champion:429}} have kits that, with enough mechanical skill, can complete shut out opponents (skillshot and mêlée champions, respectively), making the match up mostly dependant on the Yasuo/Kalista player's mechanics and mistakes, rather than a fair match of the two players' skills against each other.

The first kind of complexity is great.  The second kind of complexity is one of the things that I really hate in League of Legends.

> Do you think we're skewing too far on particular kind of complexity? Is it more of an overall complexity? Other thoughts? Fire away! I tend to prefer champs that lean more on the simple side myself, so really want to get a sense of how other players feel.

A fair point about strategic complexity. I am more worried about excessive mechanical complexity but complexity in general isn't automatically a good thing. I'd say this is mostly right but I'd put bard on moderate mechanics just due to his passive/combos.

Yeah, I can see moving Bard to moderate mechanics - his skills do require some specific positioning and aim to use properly, beyond just normal skillshot aiming.

To answer your original question in the thread, I do think we'll continue to release champions who are on the simpler side for mechanics. The trick is to do it while still adding new, unique, and fun characters to the game - but I think that's entirely doable. I've been pretty excited by the champs we're working on, and I think we have some that will match what you're looking for.

*(standard disclaimer that stuff in development can change, so no guarantees of course)*

People in this conversation keep saying Yasuo is complex, but I disagree in relation to this question. Mechanically speaking, Yasuo has:
Q: Poke that can proc auto attack effects and crits, since mana isn't a management problem, landing it a few times in a row creates relatively simple ranged poke that can become initiation
W: Blocks particles, used defensively for escapes or safe farming, something useful for a melee champ
E: Allows Yasuo to position to land his poke, or escape/chase through an enemy's own minions
R: Does one of the things a good melee champs ult should do, allows Yasuo to initiate for his team or without their help. Without it, he lacks any real way to initiate effectively without a teammate. All he has to do to initiate is land his "relatively" simple combo. This also allows for nice synergy with teamates that allow him to ult without even having to land his Q.

TLDR: Yasuo has a high skill floor and ceiling, but this is because his kit is simple an unique enough to be combined into something powerful, albeit more complex.

You have to be skilled to land your q if the other laner has half a brain. Your e you have to usually make sure is stacked. If your low, you have to have the reflexes of Drax from GOTG (sorry, had to reference) to block stuff like a nid spear, jinx ult, ashe ult, draven ult, ez ult, any other potential projectile in the game, etc. And your ult can be your death if you just hit it whenever. And, put them all together, and it is a very complex champ. Add that to being a squishy fighter, and he has a hard learning curve.

I think the most egregious example of overly mechanical champs in that bunch would be Yasuo.

I don't think he's OP, he just has such complicated and stuffed kits that it makes really confusing problems. Poor Yasuo has such a cool concept, but a few things are just... unnecessary. I mean, think of how much of his power budget could be put towards numbers and scalings if he didn't have double crit, if Flow was an actual resource he had to manage, if his ult didn't give him armor pen, etc. (That last one bugs me the most; it's counter intuitive that the super-cool shrieking anime-dunk doesn't do the killing damage, it just sets up him cleaning up kills with autos and basic abilities.)

Besides the fact that it's hard to balance right, it also sucks for new players going against him. God I remember the first twenty times I faced him as a mage, it felt like 90% of the time I literally couldn't touch him with skill shots. He either wind walled it, dashed to a minion to dodge, and if he can't actually outplay me, don't worry, he gets a Get Out of Jail Flow. Meanwhile, I've been blowing mana on trying to damage a manaless champion. That never ends well.

Now I know how to bait out stuff like that, and he really isn't a huge problem in lane anymore (no more than any AD assassin) but I distinctly remember being on the verge of quitting league because I felt like he was literally invincible against mages.

Speaking of mages!

{{champion:161}} I started league a long time ago, playing old xerath as my main. Never really was big on league, kind of lost interest. Wasn't that fun, always got my ass beat, lost contact with the friends that played it. 

Flash forward to march 2014. I'm in college, meet a lot of new people, turns out they play league. I get back into it, see a tentacle mage monster is on free week, try him out.

Instantly fell in love, been maining him ever since. Vel'Koz is why I'm playing league today. I'm really not in any place to make an objective analysis on him because of that, but holy shit I love Vel'Koz so much for so many reasons I could rant about forever. Really though, looking back, it's nice how simple he was to pick up as a new player. 

Passive, land three spells for bonus damage.
Q, shoots straight, splits in two. Can detonate early. Slows.
W, shoots straight, does damage twice. Highest damage, no CC.
E, ground-target, knock up.
R, go Alderaan on their asses. Slows.

It took only a few games to understand what his combos were and why. "Oh, I never lead with W; use Q or E to set it up with CC, and complete the passive stack. Makes sense." "Oh, wow, shouldn't use the E as initiation most of the time, since it's my only real defense." "Oh wow, I'm pretty defenseless while ulting, better choose when and where I use it carefully."

All of the complexity and learning wasn't memorizing a laundry list of mechanics and debuffs; it was emergent, resulting from some very simple abilities. I like seeing this in champs, and I think it happens more often than not. Really, I think Yasuo and Kalista are the only overly mechanical champions you listed.

Sorry if I miss a point made in a previous comment, I did my best to read most of it and gather how the conversation is flowing.

Now, I feel a huge problem with this conversation is defining "Simple". We can have (what I consider) "simple" champions in terms of mechanics (e.g. Sona, Udyr, old Soraka, Sion, Malph). We also have (again, what I consider) "simple" champions in terms of how to play them (e.g. Annie, Amumu, Caitlyn, Irelia) because even if the mechanics are not so simple they remain mostly a "straight forward" champion once you learn how to play them. You can also have a "simple" champion from the perspective of their roles (e.g. Morgana is quite easier to play as a mid laner than as a support IMO; you have to micro manage your cd's way more effectively to have an impact as a support).

So I guess the contribution I'm trying to make here is to state not only your "simple" champion example but also to explain a little bit on why or how you define it as simple. If you ask me Rammus is a simple champion in terms of mechanics, but if you truly want to be effective for your team, even knowing when to select him is as complex as it goes. Even in the proper team comp, he is also very situational when it comes to team fights. Do you want to CC the adc to abuse your W and Thronmail combo? or, do you want to remove that mid laner who can 1v4 the rest of your team?  

I know this is a short example (and I love baby {{champion:33}} ) but lets go and give more insight in our comments ;)

Rammus is a simple champ. Making targeting decisions doesn't make the champ complex. Caitlyn isn't complex. Irelia isn't complex. Annie isn't complex. Amumu isn't really complex. Sona/Udyr/Raka/Sion/Malph aren't complex. They have either point and click abilities, direct abilities, simple abilities and not weird effects that you couldn't understand exactly after trying to play them. Complex champs are champs with a ton of abilities, a billion mobility/skill shot abilities which are all hard to use (Leblanc/Zed) exct. 

I like complex champs but do you really think that 100% of league should be skill shots? Doesn't that disproportionately benefit champs like hecarim or fast MS champs?

To be honest from a design perspective I value champions that add something new regardless of their mechanics being simple or complex. A prime example of this would be Vi. She is very straight forward, her passive is quite simple to understand and her Ult some people might say its a no-brainer. However, if you really think carefully about it, her kit (although simple) is quite creative, has a lot of synergy with several champions, her Q is not that hard to pull when it comes to wall jumping (unlike Riven or Nid, who required a bit more practice) and yet she felt truly unique and innovative.

At the end of the day Vi has all these mobility bonuses and even her Q is a skill shot (sort of), yet she still remains simple. So, I do believe Riot will keep releasing new champs with simple kits, its only a matter of the character's designed background and personality inspiring them in that direction (like it did when Vi was created).
